natural problem: Find the remainder when $24^{50} - 15^{50}$ is divided by 13.
natural solution: We cleverly use these congruences to set up values that vanish in the arithmetic: $$ 24^{50} - 15^{50} \equiv (-2)^{50} - 2^{50} \equiv 2^{50} - 2^{50} \equiv \boxed{0} \pmod{13}. $$

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a b :: real
assumes h0 : "a = 24 powr 50 - 15 powr 50"
and h1 : "\<exists> q. a = 13 * q + b"
shows  "b = 0"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find the remainder when $24^{50} - 15^{50}$ is divided by 13. The final Answer is 0
 ### Proof
 We note that $24 \equiv -2 \pmod{13}$ and $15 \equiv 2 \pmod{13}$.
 We cleverly use these congruences to set up values that vanish in the arithmetic: $$ 24^{50} - 15^{50} \equiv (-2)^{50} - 2^{50} \equiv 2^{50} - 2^{50} \equiv \boxed{0} \pmod{13}. $$
 *)

theorem
fixes a b :: real
assumes h0 : "a = 24 powr 50 - 15 powr 50"
and h1 : "\<exists> q. a = 13 * q + b"
shows  "b = 0"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Find the remainder when $24^{50} - 15^{50}$ is divided by 13. The final answer is 0.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x y :: real and P Q R :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x = 24 powr 50 - 15 powr 50"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. Q x = 13"
and h2 : "\<exists> r. \<forall> x. P x = Q x * R x + r"
shows  "\<forall> r. r = 0"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find the remainder when $24^{50} - 15^{50}$ is divided by 13. The final Answer is 0
 ### Proof
 We note that $24 \equiv -2 \pmod{13}$ and $15 \equiv 2 \pmod{13}$.
 We cleverly use these congruences to set up values that vanish in the arithmetic: $$ 24^{50} - 15^{50} \equiv (-2)^{50} - 2^{50} \equiv 2^{50} - 2^{50} \equiv \boxed{0} \pmod{13}. $$
 *)

theorem
fixes x y :: real and P Q R :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x = 24 powr 50 - 15 powr 50"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. Q x = 13"
and h2 : "\<exists> r. \<forall> x. P x = Q x * R x + r"
shows  "\<forall> r. r = 0"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Given that $P(x) = 24^{50} - 15^{50}$ and $Q(x) = 13$, for some $r$, $P(x) = Q(x) \cdot R(x) + r$ holds for all $x$. Prove that $r$ must be 0.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x y n :: int
assumes h0 : "x = 24 powr 50 - 15 powr 50"
and h1 : "n = 13"
and h2 : "x mod n = 0"
shows  "x mod n = 0"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find the remainder when $24^{50} - 15^{50}$ is divided by 13. The final Answer is 0
 ### Proof
 We note that $24 \equiv -2 \pmod{13}$ and $15 \equiv 2 \pmod{13}$.
 We cleverly use these congruences to set up values that vanish in the arithmetic: $$ 24^{50} - 15^{50} \equiv (-2)^{50} - 2^{50} \equiv 2^{50} - 2^{50} \equiv \boxed{0} \pmod{13}. $$
 *)

theorem
fixes x y n :: int
assumes h0 : "x = 24 powr 50 - 15 powr 50"
and h1 : "n = 13"
and h2 : "x mod n = 0"
shows  "x mod n = 0"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: What is the remainder when the difference between $24^{50}$ and $15^{50}$ is divided by $13$? The final answer is $0$.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x y :: real and P Q :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x = 24 powr 50 - 15 powr 50"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. Q x = x mod 13"
and h2 : "Q (P x) = 0"
shows  "Q (P x) = 0"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find the remainder when $24^{50} - 15^{50}$ is divided by 13. The final Answer is 0
 ### Proof
 We note that $24 \equiv -2 \pmod{13}$ and $15 \equiv 2 \pmod{13}$.
 We cleverly use these congruences to set up values that vanish in the arithmetic: $$ 24^{50} - 15^{50} \equiv (-2)^{50} - 2^{50} \equiv 2^{50} - 2^{50} \equiv \boxed{0} \pmod{13}. $$
 *)

theorem
fixes x y :: real and P Q :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x = 24 powr 50 - 15 powr 50"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. Q x = x mod 13"
and h2 : "Q (P x) = 0"
shows  "Q (P x) = 0"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: For any real number $x$, let $P(x) = 24^{50} - 15^{50}$ and $Q(x)$ be the remainder when $x$ is divided by $13$. If $Q(P(x)) = 0$, then prove that the remainder when $P(x)$ is divided by $13$ is $0$.
